urn:contentItem:5MW7-54F1-JD34-V02M-00000-00State forest ripped to bits2017-02-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisState forest ripped to bitsWilliam Vallely

The state government has sabotaged protected crown land by deliberately tearing down trees in the Whroo state forest in the interest of "public safety".

A five-kilometre stretch of a well-travelled historic Gold and Ironbark trail near Rushworth is now littered with hundreds of fallen trees and jagged tree stumps, making the environment dangerous to the public.

Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning uprooted the trees to prevent illegal motor cross riders using the trail.

"We felt that was an effective way of closing the track. Signage failed to do so," Forest Fire Management Victoria District Manager for the department, Paul Bates said.

"We have ongoing use of a track that isn't inspected and maintained."

There is currently no signs on the Gold and Ironbark trail showing potential hazards for the public, however Mr Bates said signage was going up soon indicating the track was closed to riders, which he hoped would "be enough".

"Walkers can step over (fallen) and walk around the track. Mountain bikers can use the proper road," he said.

As the trail in the forest was not officially a public road, the department were not required to consult the public, however Mr Bates admitted they could "potentially have told people".

"We had no intention of doing it secretly the decision was made because of increasing use of it," he said.

"It looks a little unsightly at present."

Recreational bike rider John Salter, who discovered the devastation on Saturday, said the department's actions had left locals "devastated".

"Someone has gone rogue and done something terrible," he said.

Founder of the Rushworth Off Road Cycling Association, Cameron McGavin, said he "couldn't fathom what reason the department had for doing this".

Mr McGavin said the path was frequented by locals and was a huge tourist and environmental drawcard for the area.

In his 10 years of mountain biking across Victoria, Mr McGavin said he had never seen anything like this.

"Some of the more adventurous riders will see this as a challenge and take it on, but that's not what we want," he said.

Despite the forest being protected, Mr Bates said it was managed under the requirements of the Forest Act, and as such the department could make decisions to protect and maintain it.

urn:contentItem:5RBH-NW91-F0J6-J45V-00000-00The man working sky-high above Bendigo2018-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisSATURDAYThe man working sky-high above Bendigo

Perched sky-high above Bendigo is the One Tree Hill fire spotting tower, manned by Forest Fire Management Victoria's Daryl Anderson, Bendigo's eye in the sky.

With a panoramic view stretching from Mount Macedon to Mount Ida, north up to Echuca and back around to Mount Tarrengower, his job is to spot any bushfires.

"Local knowledge is fairly important," Mr Anderson said.

"I have a fairly good knowledge of the layout of the land, both in the town and the district."

"Local knowledge is a bit underrated and it's important because one of it's advantages, if I see something, I need to get a bearing and instantly refer to it on a large-scale map, so I can see the line between the tower and the fire."

The threat of bushfires can change on a day-to-day basis dependent on the external environmental factors such as temperature, humidity and wind strength which are then combined to determine the fire danger index.

Mr Anderson said he has been in the role for "the best bit of 20 years" and it's essential to understand the visual differences between the similarities of a dust storm and smoke from fires.

"The last thing, especially volunteers, want to do is chase dust all day, but generally all of us get it right," he laughed.

During days of operation Mr Anderson will communicate every hour with all eight towers within the Murray Goldfields district which includes Mount Macedon, Mount Ida, Growlers Hill and Mount Brananah.

"It's fair to say that during the usual fire season, the role is pretty constant."

The hourly check-in confirms that all fire towers are free from visible smoke and they also help ground crew, the various depots and the CFA keep up-to-date with any activity.

"Particularly on high fire danger days when there are plenty of people out in the field," he said.

"The controllers and those organising research need to know where the incident is, how quickly it's gathering, the nature of the fire, because smoke colour can give an indication of what type of fire it is," he said.

Mr Anderson said a crucial element of the role is communicating wind changes to crews that are fighting fires on the ground.

"Sometimes there's a very immediate and distinct change of wind, it may go from a northerly and instantly swing around and come from the west."

"Those on the flank are exposed to the head of the fire, and they want, and need to know when the wind changes because the flank of the fire can very quickly become the head, and they can be in immediate danger."

Mr Anderson still recounts the Black Saturday bushfires in 2009 as the worst incident he has observed at the One Tree Hill fire tower.

urn:contentItem:5XJ5-5VK1-F0JP-W0X5-00000-00The art of being prepared2019-11-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisLIFESTYLEPg. 24The art of being preparedwith Genevieve Barlow

Miranda Adapting to a changed environment means building in disaster management as a way of life THERE'S not much more to add to the conversation about the failure of political leadership on climate change in Australia.

Glen Innes Severn mayor Carol Sparks said many of the conversations were "ill-informed" and "uneducated".

Cr Sparks' ABC interview and column in The Guardian, in such shocking and personally devastating circumstances after fire had ripped through her community, hospitalising members of her own family, said it all.

"It's not a political thing," she said. "It's a scientific fact that we are going through climate change.

"Of course it's not relevant at the moment when people's houses are burning and you've lost lives and you've lost friends and you've lost family.

"But the overall thing is we are so dry in this country ... and to deny climate change is, to me, a very ill-informed and uneducated way of looking at things." Hopefully her words and the experiences of those in these current fires - in which farmers defending their properties reported embers hitting 10 and 12km ahead of the fire front - will bring our federal, state and local governments together. They can then declare a national climate emergency and begin a joint strategy, for curbing our emissions faster than we are currently committed to and for adapting to a changed environment.

It will take many years before emissions curbed globally, not just locally, will have an impact.

In the meantime, adapting to a changing environment means building in disaster management as a way of life.

What we are learning is that no matter how well prepared we are, the intensity of fires in parched conditions presents an almost unassailable circumstance.

So it's with this in mind that Victoria - parched in Gippsland and the northwest, dry in others parts and deep in lush vegetation in others - is, hopefully, listening carefully to the observations of those experiencing fire now.

Here's one: "We thought we were prepared," NSW beef and soybean producer Carolyn Duff told the ABC.

"We know the country, we know fires, we are prepared," said Carolyn, whose farm at Toorooka in the Upper Macleay Valley was burnt out.

"And we have never seen anything like this ever. It is catastrophic and you will never beat it. Looking back now and after going through it, we were never ever going to stop it.

"It was igniting 12 kilometres in front of the fire." There's plenty more like this to read on news websites.

Our CFA is warning of high-consequence fires this summer.

It's reporting increased fuel loads and flammability in many of our forests and a rainfall deficit in line with historically severe forest fire seasons.

All of which means we have to prepare well at home and rethink whether we will go or stay in the face of fire.

So, for country communities, here are some reminders.

In the Black Saturday fires of February 2009, of the 173 people who died, 113 perished inside their homes and a further 27 just outside them. Eleven died in cars fleeing the fires. A further 10 died on roadways. Many people successfully escaped approaching flames by car.

Research by the then Bushfire Co-operative Research Centre from the fire at Murrindindi that day found that: IF MOST community members believe that their community is not at risk, most individuals will be psychologically unready to make sound, survival-related decisions under imminent bushfire threat. (Communities influence individuals' decisions via shared, normative beliefs about bushfire risk.) INFORMATION and advice from close family members and from people perceived to have bushfire-related expertise (firefighters, SES, police) will be extremely influential. (Advice and information from particular others will be a major determinant of an individual's decisions - the more so under conditions of uncertainty.) WHAT others are observed to be doing is an important determinant of an individual's decision making. People are social beings, and take their cues about what to do by noting what others are doing in a given situation - especially a situation characterised by uncertainty.

MEN are more likely to stay and defend their property; women are more likely to leave - especially if they have strong feelings of responsibility for the physical or psychological wellbeing of other family members.

THE legendary "Murphy" was an optimist with regards to bushfires. All involved should be warned to expect and be ready for something really important going seriously wrong at the worst possible time - with potentially fatal consequences.

PEOPLE aged under 18 or 70-plus, those with disabilities or other impairments - physical, social, psychological - should not be in a situation where they are at risk of bushfire attack.

IN EXTREMIS, an individual's ability to: regulate emotions such as fear and anxiety; focus on emerging threats from the environment; and keep actions focused on surviving in a potentially lethal environment will largely determine survival.FOR a variety of complex reasons, some individuals will choose to act in ways that jeopardise their safety, and the safety of others.

urn:contentItem:5VJP-S161-JD3N-53K8-00000-00Crown land growth 'fuelled fire'2019-03-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 3Crown land growth 'fuelled fire'Rachel Baxendale, Chip Le Grand

Residents of a small rural community heaviest hit by Victoria's weekend bushfires believe dan-g-er-ously high fuel loads on vacant- crown land contributed to the feroci-ty of a blaze that left Country Fire Authority firefighters unable to defend some properties.

The quiet hamlet of Tonimbuk, about 90km east of Melbourne, felt the brunt of the fire crisis, with seven properties destroyed and 11,000ha burnt by a lightning-strike blaze that raced out of the Bunyip State Forest.

Andrew Clarke, the owner of the Jinks Creek Winery destroyed by the Bunyip fire, believes a bureaucrati-c blunder cost him his life's work.

He said a planned burn-off in 60ha between his vineyard and the state park was not done because of concerns for local birdlife.

"If they'd been doing the burning off they should have been doing, our place might still be there," he told The Australian.

"They told me birds were nesting. I told them: 'If we don't do a burn-off now, there'll be no birds. There'll be no goannas, no snakes, no wallabies. They'll all be bar-becued." Another Tonimbuk resident, cartoonist Mark Knight, said some residents were left to defend their homes without assistance from the CFA.

"We fought this fire for three days on our own," he said. "Black Saturday they were all over us. They were fantastic. We didn't see them this year." Rex Newton, 70, returned to his Tonimbuk home and wildlife refuge- yesterday to find it burnt to the ground. He said he was near the rear of his property when he saw fire race over a hill towards his back door.

"I only have the clothes on my back and it isn't that nice a shirt," he told the ABC as he sifted through ash and twisted metal. By the time he managed to load his dog, cat and cockatoo and jump into a car, the fire had singed the hair on his arms.

Firefighting resources have been stretched to breaking point, with more than 2000 personnel deployed to contain nearly 20 significant- fires across the state.

Although the crisis had abated last night, emergency services were bracing for the impact of a viole-nt weather change expected to bring strong winds, lightning strikes and possibly snow to some of the same alpine areas scorched by fire.

A Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesman, when asked why fuel reduction burning had not been carried out on the crown land next to the Bunyip State Park, said that under a change to fire risk management, burning had become- more targeted.

"We are using a risk-reduction target to focus our fuel-management strategies on areas that will have the greatest impact," the spokesman said. "This target means we are burning smarter, rather than focusing on a number-of-hectares target.

"In some cases this may mean less planned burns - in other areas it may mean more - but communities can be assured that our activities are focused on making them safer and protecting their local environment." The immediate threat shifted yesterday from Tonimbuk to the alpine town of Dargo, where the small community was at one point menaced by two bushfires.

Leanne Estcourt said from insid-e the historic Dargo Hotel that the town was encircled by smoke, with the skies glowing lumin-ous orange. Some town residents sought shelter in the pub.

"We have got some people that are here that the fires are affecting their properties as we speak, and the phones are going crazy because we have got the department ringing us all the time," Ms Estcourt said. "It is pretty stressful when you don't know the situation and how bad it is." By late afternoon, the threat to properties in Dargo had eased, althoug-h the fires were not under control.

The Tonimbuk fire was the worst to hit the area since Black Saturday 10 years ago, when a fire which began in the Bunyip State Park destroyed 31 houses and burnt more than 26,000ha.

Graeme Moore, the Mayor of Cardinia Shire, which takes in Tonimbuk, said his community had been hammered by the fire but praised the CFA.Additional reporting: Tessa Akerman

urn:contentItem:5VJG-4XN1-JD34-V4M6-00000-00Houses lost in Bunyip blaze2019-03-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Houses lost in Bunyip blazeJoe Hinchliffe and Matilda Boseley

Firefighters and residents were bracing for more homes to be lost to a massive, out-of-control bushfire threatening at least seven Gippsland towns east of Melbourne overnight.

At least three homes were destroyed by the 10,000 hectare Bunyip fire yesterday, including one at Tonimbuk that exploded as it was engulfed in flames. Two homes were also lost in the Budgeree-Wilsons Promontory fires.

Hundreds of firefighters were battling to contain the Bunyip blaze, as residents bunkered down in evacuation centres, not knowing if their homes would be among those lost.

The Bunyip fire razed homes and sheds, and incinerated vineyards yesterday.

While many residents chose to stay and defend their homes, others were forced to do so after being told it was too late to leave, after the Princes Freeway was closed in both directions between Nar Nar Goon and Drouin.

The freeway, and many other local roads, could remain closed for days. Drouin Secondary College will be closed today also.

Hundreds of people were left without power, with around 550 homes cut off around 2.40pm yesterday at Gembrook, Maryknoll, Nar Nar Goon and Tynong.

The severity of the blaze prompted the Premier Daniel Andrews to implore people not to risk their lives - and put others in danger. "Don't put yourself in harm's way and potentially add to the already considerable workload our firefighters have," he said.

Late yesterday afternoon firefighters began focusing on their own safety, on high alert for a wind change which was expected to make conditions even more unpredictable and dangerous.

More than 850 of them fought to control the blaze sparked by lightning strikes on Friday night, using 100 fire trucks, 18 heavy machines and 10 aircraft.

Meanwhile, campers and daytrippers had to be evacuated from Wilsons Promontory, due to a fire north of Tidal River.

At 5.30pm, authorities issued emergency warnings for two other large fires at Yinnar South and Dargo, while a fourth major blaze raged near Licola. Despite the wind switching from the north-westerly to south-easterly direction, bringing cooler conditions, firefighters may have to wait until Wednesday before a cold front brings "limited rain".

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Chris Eagle said the Bunyip fire in Gippsland had "significantly expanded" yesterday afternoon.

Mr Eagle said he expected more homes would be lost once the ash and smoke had cleared.

"We had three [destroyed properties] confirmed this morning, but given the fire's grown over 4000 hectares today, more will be impacted," he said.

Mr Eagle said he expected the Princes Freeway would remain closed in both directions between Nar Nar Goon and Drouin for several days, as well as many other local roads in the affected area.

Lightning strikes ignited the blaze on Friday night and four separate fires morphed into one on Saturday.

Yesterday, the fire burnt dangerously close to two electricity transmission lines linking the Latrobe Valley and Melbourne. "Firefighters are protecting these transmission lines, both on the ground and through water bombing from the air," a company statement said.

The lines are running at the north of the fire and at the southern border, near the Princes Freeway. The company operates Victoria's electricity transmission network and said supply could be exposed to risk.

"However the situation is unpredictable, and may change quickly," the statement said.

Fire had already damaged power lines and poles in the Gippsland area with outages reported in Toninbuk, Yinnar South and Budgeree.

Residents of Labertouche were door knocked and told to evacuate yesterday afternoon.

Others in areas including Bunyip, Cornucopia, Garfield, Gentle Annie, Longwarry, Maryknoll, Nar Nar Goon, Tonimbuk and Tynong were told it was too late to leave and to take shelter immediately. Three relief centres have been set up for residents.

Two homes were also lost in the Budgeree-Wilsons Promontory fires, incident controller for those blazes, Peter West, told the ABC.

"Unfortunately we've had confirmed two house losses with the fire and some unconfirmed reports about other assets," Mr West said of the Budgeree fire.

With Liam Mannix, AAP

urn:contentItem:5RBH-NW91-F0J6-J465-00000-00The man working sky-high above Bendigo2018-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATEThe man working sky-high above Bendigo

Perched sky-high above Bendigo is the One Tree Hill fire spotting tower, manned by Forest Fire Management Victoria's Daryl Anderson, Bendigo's eye in the sky.

With a panoramic view stretching from Mount Macedon to Mount Ida, north up to Echuca and back around to Mount Tarrengower, his job is to spot any bushfires.

"Local knowledge is fairly important," Mr Anderson said.

"I have a fairly good knowledge of the layout of the land, both in the town and the district."

"Local knowledge is a bit underrated and it's important because one of it's advantages, if I see something, I need to get a bearing and instantly refer to it on a large-scale map, so I can see the line between the tower and the fire."

The threat of bushfires can change on a day-to-day basis dependent on the external environmental factors such as temperature, humidity and wind strength which are then combined to determine the fire danger index.

Mr Anderson said he has been in the role for "the best bit of 20 years" and it's essential to understand the visual differences between the similarities of a dust storm and smoke from fires.

"The last thing, especially volunteers, want to do is chase dust all day, but generally all of us get it right," he laughed.

During days of operation Mr Anderson will communicate every hour with all eight towers within the Murray Goldfields district which includes Mount Macedon, Mount Ida, Growlers Hill and Mount Brananah.

"It's fair to say that during the usual fire season, the role is pretty constant."

The hourly check-in confirms that all fire towers are free from visible smoke and they also help ground crew, the various depots and the CFA keep up-to-date with any activity.

"Particularly on high fire danger days when there are plenty of people out in the field," he said.

"The controllers and those organising research need to know where the incident is, how quickly it's gathering, the nature of the fire, because smoke colour can give an indication of what type of fire it is," he said.

Mr Anderson said a crucial element of the role is communicating wind changes to crews that are fighting fires on the ground.

"Sometimes there's a very immediate and distinct change of wind, it may go from a northerly and instantly swing around and come from the west."

"Those on the flank are exposed to the head of the fire, and they want, and need to know when the wind changes because the flank of the fire can very quickly become the head, and they can be in immediate danger."

Mr Anderson still recounts the Black Saturday bushfires in 2009 as the worst incident he has observed at the One Tree Hill fire tower.

urn:contentItem:5DN0-9RB1-JD3N-52KJ-00000-00Mock fire sparks full response from emergency team2014-11-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Mock fire sparks full response from emergency team

A HIGH-intensity, real-time strategic exercise held last week has helped one local council determine how it would respond to a rapidly spreading forest fire.

The mock disaster saw a fast-spreading fire in Daisy Hill threaten hundreds of homes, an aged care facility, schools and vital infrastructure, leaving just hours for emergency services to act.

Hundreds of people needed evacuation, electricity to the area had to be cut, roads closed, and emergency messages communicated to residents all in two to three hours.

Logan City deputy mayor and deputy chair of the Local Disaster Management Group Councillor Russell Lutton said Exercise Swelter enabled member agencies of the Logan Local Disaster Management Group to steer through a real-time disaster management simulation.

He said representatives from Logan City Council, Queensland Police Service, Queensland Fire and Emergency Service, State Emergency Service, Red Cross, Energex, Department of Transport and Main Roads and Logan Water took part.

He said the mock disaster provided the opporunity to discuss priorities, tactics, planning and communication during a serious bushfire.

"We have already seen a spell of hot, dry weather and looking ahead to summer, that is forecast to continue," he said."It is a time when we all need to be prepared, both residents and the organisations those residents rely on to assist them."Visit logan.qld.gov.au

urn:contentItem:5XGW-8R61-F0JP-W1SD-00000-00Homes' survival chances up 25pc if owner fights2019-11-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 4Homes' survival chances up 25pc if owner fightsJAMIE WALKER ASSOCIATE EDITOR, EXCLUSIVE

Research led by an expert consultant to the royal commission into the Black Saturday bushfire disaster has found that homes are up to 25 per cent more likely to be saved if an owner stays to fight the flames.

The conclusions by professor Ross Bradstock and research fellow- Owen Price will reignite the "stay or go" debate, as the crisis gripping the eastern seaboard escalat-es in Queensland, where residents of a subdivision on the Sunshine Coast were evacuated for the second time in five days, one of four communities to be cleared on Wednesday.

Amid the drama, a helicopter engaged in waterbombing crashed at Pechey on the Darling Downs, west of Brisbane, injuring the pilot. The bright yellow machine came to grief in a blustery weather change that ramped up the threat level across the thickly populated southeast corner, pitching on to its side when forced into an emergency landing.

Amazingly, the pilot walked away with a head gash; residents of Pechey had earlier been advised to leave because of the severity of the bushfire danger.

Weary fire crews were hard-pressed to cover dozens of blazes that flared in the heat and strong winds, flowing on from the searing conditions in NSW on Tuesday. The uncontained Cobraball fire near Yeppoon on the Queensland central coast continued to menace homes and rural properties: it has accounted for 13 of the 14 houses lost in the state since late last week.

Professor Bradstock's team from the University of Wollongong's Centre for Environmental Risk Management of Bushfires reviewed- data and interviewed people caught up in the 2013 Blue Mountains disaster, west of -Sydney, to understand why their homes were destroyed or spared.

More than 200 homes went up when fierce blazes ripped through the communities of Springwood, Winmalee and Yellow Rock six years ago.

The researchers found that dwellings with a separation of at least 40m from forest or bushland were most likely to be saved, -reinforcing the findings of the Black Saturday inquiry as well as studies overseas.

But the next most important factor was the presence of one or more residents, the as-yet-unpublished study revealed. If someone stayed to defend the property with support from trained firefighters, the probability of destruction dropped by up to 25 per cent against doing nothing.

"We have pretty strong -evidence that property defence by the agencies and also the owners who are properly prepared makes a big difference," Professor -Bradstock said.

"So stay and defend still has validity, but how the authorities nuance that message is a challenge." Since the Black Saturday carnage in Victoria on February 7, 2009, in which 173 people were killed and more than 2000 homes were razed, fire authorities have accepted that a catastrophic rating of 100 or more on the Forest Fire Danger Index would overwhelm efforts by even the best-prepared householder to defend a property.

Increasingly this spring, the Rural Fire Service in NSW and the Queensland Fire and Emergency Services have urged people to leave in the face of severe or emergency-level blazes.

As detailed in Inquirer on page 11, parts of the country are burning that have never before been -impacted by severe bushfire, including- iconic rainforests.

Since the razing in September of the Binna Burra Lodge on the Gold Coast hinterland, backing on to a World Heritage-listed reserve of virgin Gondwana rainforest, other importan-t wet subtropical forests have burned at Terania Creek in the famed Nightcap Nation-al Park near Lismore, northeast NSW, while parts of the region's usually luxuriant Clarence Valley have been blackened.

The towering moss-lined Antarctic beech forests at Wauchope, inland of Coffs Harbour, remain under threat. Rainforest expert and fire ecologist David Bowman, of the University of Tasmania, said: "To think that those iconic rainforests are burning is very discombobulating." Professor Bradstock, who sat on the expert panel for land manageme-nt at the Black Saturday inquiry, said the fire danger index was in the process of being overhauled under a national initiative- headed by the NSWRFS.

Currently, it covers only temperatur-e, humidity, wind speed and an approximation of drought-related dryness to gauge the level of bushfire threat.

"With great fairness to the invent-ors, it's a very antiquated system and we can do much better now," he told The Australian.

Fanned by the swirling winds, flames from the Cooroibah outbreak on the Sunshine Coast advance-d on properties at Noosa North Shore, forcing the precinct's evacuation for the second time since the weekend. The situation was described by firefighters as "very dangerous" before residents were urged to flee. People at -Kilkivan, west of Gympie, and Woodgate near Bundaberg were also told to leave their homes.

The Insurance Council of Aust-ralia extended a catastrophe declar-ation in NSW to Yeppoon and the Sunshine Coast after putting- the cost of bushfire-related claims at $50m to date, with the figure expected to grow.

Conditions are forecast to ease on Thursday in Queensland, before building up again at the weekend. Authorities in NSW warned that strengthening winds meant properties were still at risk there.

urn:contentItem:5KRN-6TT1-JD34-V2C8-00000-00Indonesian toxic haze toll '100,000'2016-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Indonesian toxic haze toll '100,000'Jewel Topsfield - Jakarta

Killer haze from forest fires that raged across Indonesia last year may have caused more than 100,000 premature deaths in Indonesia, Singapore and Malaysia, according to a new report that suggests a drastically higher death toll than Indonesian government estimates.

Harvard and Columbia University researchers used air pollution readings to calculate exposure to the deadly smoke.

"We estimate that haze in 2015 resulted in 100,300 excess deaths across Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore," says the report, published in Environmental Research Letters journal on September 19.

It says this is more than double the estimated number of deaths as a result of haze in 2006, with much of the increase due to fires in Indonesia's South Sumatra province.

"Exposure to air pollution increases the risk of death from a number of ailments including stroke and respiratory illnesses," one of the researchers from Harvard University, Dr Shannon Koplitz, told Fairfax Media.

Indonesians were the worst affected with an estimated 91,600 excess deaths.

However Indonesia's disaster agency said just 24 people had died due to the 2015 fires, 12 of whom were killed fighting the fires and 12 from respiratory problems as a result of the haze.

"There is nothing like that (91,000 premature deaths)," Sutopo Purwo Nugroho, from the National Disaster Management Agency (BNPB), said.

"It is not true. The data is not valid. If there were high numbers of people dead we would have stated it in our almost daily forest fire press releases last year."

Last year the agency estimated that 43 million Indonesians were exposed to the smog in Sumatra and Kalimantan alone and there were half a million cases of respiratory tract infections.

Forest fires are an annual event in Indonesia, caused in part by "slash and burn" agriculture techniques.

Last year's dry conditions, exacerbated by the El Nino effect, resulted in the worst haze in the region since 1997.

Six Indonesian provinces declared a state of emergency, schools were closed in Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia, flights were grounded and warships were put on standby to evacuate people from the toxic haze.

urn:contentItem:5XJ2-GBK1-F0J6-J1G9-00000-00NSW RFS updates fire spread predictions for Tuesday2019-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNSW RFS updates fire spread predictions for Tuesday

UPDATED 3PM:

Updated fire prediction maps for North Coast fires have been issued, based on latest observations and forecasts.

More areas are included in risk zone if fires take a run as expected today, including Wauchope, NSWRFS said on Twitter.

See the updated map to the right/above.

An emergency warning has been issued for the Wine Country Dr, North Rothbury (Cessnock LGA) fire at 2:56pm.

The RFS says "the fire is burning in the area of Wine Country Drive at North Rothbury and spreading quickly. Property is under threat. If you are in the area, it is too late to leave. Seek shelter."

The Whans Rd, Llangothlin (Armidale LGA) fire has been downgraded to Watch and Act due to improved conditions, the RFS tweeted at 2:47pm. "Residents in the area should continue to monitor the conditions and take advice from firefighters on the ground."

An emergency warning has been issued for the Rumba Dump (Mid-Coast LGA) Fire at 2:42pm. The RFS says the fire is "spreading quickly towards Elands, Bobin and Marlee and areas NW of Wingham. Seek shelter."

An emergency warning has been issued for the Kian Rd (Nambucca LGA) fire at 2:26pm. The RFS says "the fire has breached containment lines and is burning towards Macksville. If you're near Talarm, Macksville, Allgomera Creek, seek shelter as the fire approaches. Protect yourself from the heat of the fire."

An emergency warning has been issued for the Reserves Rd, Mares Run (Mid-Coast LGA) Fire at 2:11pm.

The RFS says "the fire is burning in the area of Mares Run towards Cooplacarripa and is spreading quickly. If you are in Cooplacarripa, you are at risk. It is too late to leave. Seek shelter as the fire approaches."

An emergency warning has been issued at 2pm for the Myall Creek Rd, Bora Ridge (Richmond Valley LGA) fire. The NSWRFS says "the fire is spreading quickly and is expected to impact on Bungawalbin, New Italy and The Gap Rd. If you are in the area, it is too late to leave. Seek shelter as the fire approaches."

READ MORE:

The full list of closed schools New England North West extreme fire danger live updates 'We always seem to be forgotten': Locals want more resources to fight fires Time for adult conversation on climate change An emergency warning has been issued for the Washpool State Forest Fire at 1:40pm. RFS says it "is threatening Baryulgil. If you're in Baryulgil seek shelter as the fire approaches. It is too late to leave. If you're in Eighteen Mile, Fine Flower, Dumbudgery or Carnham, monitor conditions."

An emergency warning was issued for the Liberation Trail (Clarence Valley LGA) fire at 1:30pm.

RFS says: "The fire has breached containment lines. If you are in the area of Nana Glen or Coramba and surrounding area, leave now towards Coffs Harbour. Do not wait."

An emergency warning has been issued for Hillville Road Fire (Mid-Coast LGA) as of 1:08pm.

RFS says: "The Hillville Road is spreading towards Nabiac and Failford. If you are in the areas of Nabiac, Failford, Tinonee, Purfleet and Old Bar seek shelter as the fire approaches. Protect yourself from the heat of the fire."

An emergency warning has also been issued for Carrai East Fire (Kempsey LGA) at 1:17pm. The RFS says: "The bush fire is burning west of Kempsey. The fire breached containment lines and is spreading quickly. If you are in the area west of Kempsey you are at risk. It is too late to leave. Seek shelter as the fire approaches."

At 12pm an emergency warning was also issued for Gulf Rd, Torrington (Tenterfield LGA).

RFS said: "The fire has breached containment lines and is spreading quickly. If you are in Emmaville or Stannum, seek shelter. If you are in Deepwater, monitor conditions. Be aware of smoke and embers."

Just before 12pm an emergency warning was also issued for the Thunderbolts Way, Bretti (Mid-Coast LGA) Fire. It is burning in the area of Thunderbolts Way and Nowendoc Rd and is spreading quickly. RFS advised "If you are in the Nowendoc and Mt George area, it is too late to leave. Seek shelter as the fire approaches."

Keep up-to-date with the latest here: https://www.rfs.nsw.gov.au/fire-information/fires-near-me or follow the RFS on Twitter and download the Fires Near Me app.

EARLIER: Dangerous fire conditions are expected across the Northern Tablelands and north coast on Tuesday. New England has been classified as 'Extreme'.

Under these conditions, fires will spread quickly.

Based on the latest forecast, the NSW Rural Fire Service has mapped the most likely path of these fires. These are predictions based on the best available information.

If you are in an area likely to be impacted by fires and you are not prepared, the RFS recommend you leave to a safer location before the worst of the conditions on Tuesday. This may include going to a major built-up area such as a town or a city.

These are dangerous conditions. Because of the large number of fires already burning, if you need help during a fire, you may not get it.

Detailed maps are available on the NSWRFS website. https://www.rfs.nsw.gov.au/fire-information/fires-near-me

- with the Northern Daily Leader

urn:contentItem:5MS1-K7J1-JD34-V217-00000-00Deadly ash tree hazard is gone2017-01-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisDeadly ash tree hazard is goneShana Morgan

The most dangerous Alpine ash trees, like those that killed two firefighters at Harrietville in 2013, are being removed for safety.

Forest Fire Management Victoria began removing about 100 kilometres of fire-damaged and hazardous trees from roadsides in the Ovens fire district in November and was due to be completed next month.

The works were part of a $7 million tree-removal program across Victoria.

FFMV Ovens district manager Jarrod Hayse said Alpine National Park and state forest at Mount Bogong, West Kiewa and Mount Hotham had been identified as high-risk.

"These areas have been selected due to high visitation by members of the public and emergency services access," he said.

"The tourist area is surrounded by large fire-killed Alpine ash from the 2013 Harrietville fire and the 2006-07 great Alpine fires, and care must be taken when travelling in such areas.

"Safety from hazardous trees is vital for people visiting our forests and parks and for the people who work there, particularly our firefighters undertaking fire suppression or planned burns."

Department of Sustainability and Environment firefighters Steven Kadar and Katie Peters were killed in 2013 when a tree fell on their vehicle in the Buckland Valley.

Coroner John Olle conducted an inquest and recommended the organisation "develop a protocol which best ensures that fire crews are not exposed to fire-affected Alpine ash forests unless absolutely necessary".

"In an ideal world, exposure of fire crews to hazardous trees would be eliminated altogether by finding alternative fire suppression options - in reality however, this is not always possible," he said.

"It is nevertheless critical to appropriately manage the risk posed by hazardous trees in order to minimise the potential for harm to firefighters, specifically through the identification and removal of hazardous trees."

The department agreed to implement all the coroner's findings.

Parks Victoria Kiewa and Murray area chief ranger Dave Jensen said a mechanical falling machine was used to remove hazardous trees.

"The extent of tree removal is dependent upon a number of factors, including the type of trees, the type of road and the side slope," he said.

"The felled timber will remain on the forest floor to provide fauna habitat and nutrients to the soil as the trees decompose."

urn:contentItem:5PJ7-X911-JCM0-61JY-00000-00Firefighters on standby in Mallee with Victoria's north-west facing dangerous bushfire conditions2017-09-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisFirefighters on standby in Mallee with Victoria's north-west facing dangerous bushfire conditionsBy Melissa Brown

Victoria is facing its first day of dangerous bushfire conditions this season.

Firefighters are on standby in the Mallee, in the state's north-west, where temperatures are forecast to reach the mid-30s with winds gusting up to 90 kilometres per hour.

Forest Fire Management's Scott Falconer said dry forests and predictions of possible lightning strikes are cause for concern.

"We're going from a pretty mild spring into really unexpected warm to hot weather," Mr Falconer said.

"I would describe this as a bit of a wake-up call that the season's changed."

The Mallee region reaches to the New South Wales border.

Total fire bans have been implemented across half of NSW with some parts expected to hit 40 degrees Celsius for the first time in September since records began.

"The further north you go [in Victoria], the hotter it gets," Mr Falconer said.

"And as most people would know hot temperatures and high winds are the real risk factors."

Holidaymakers warned to be extra cautious

Mr Falconer said the start of the school holidays today increased the risk.

"We anticipate that we'll have a lot of people camping up on the Murray River and in the great parks of the north-west of the state," he said

Authorities urged holidaymakers to take extra care with their camp fires, with gusty winds able to easily carry embers into the bush.

Conditions are not as severe as they are at the height of the bushfire season in January and February, but authorities said people still needed to be careful.

"But we're going into that period and certainly those sorts of temperatures and those sorts of winds really do present a potential threat to people if a fire gets out of a camp fire, for instance," Mr Falconer said.

The Southern Australian Seasonal Bushfire Outlook 2017 predicted the fire season was likely to start earlier and be more active than usual due to a warmer, dry winter and forecast of a hot summer.

Two firefighting aircraft are on standby at Stawell to respond to any fires that break out in the Mallee region.

Strong wind warnings have been issued for much of Victoria, with elevated areas warned to brace for 100 kilometre per hour winds.

But the Bureau of Meteorology warned the unseasonably warm temperatures would not last.

A cold front was expected to cross the state late on Saturday, bringing a cooler air stream.

Snow was predicted above 1,400 metres on Sunday and as low as 1,100 metres on Monday.

urn:contentItem:5MS1-K7J1-JD34-V228-00000-00Deadly ash tree hazard is gone2017-01-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Deadly ash tree hazard is goneShana Morgan

The most dangerous Alpine ash trees, like those that killed two firefighters at Harrietville in 2013, are being removed for safety.

Forest Fire Management Victoria began removing about 100 kilometres of fire-damaged and hazardous trees from roadsides in the Ovens fire district in November and was due to be completed next month.

The works were part of a $7 million tree-removal program across Victoria.

FFMV Ovens district manager Jarrod Hayse said Alpine National Park and state forest at Mount Bogong, West Kiewa and Mount Hotham had been identified as high-risk.

"These areas have been selected due to high visitation by members of the public and emergency services access," he said.

"The tourist area is surrounded by large fire-killed Alpine ash from the 2013 Harrietville fire and the 2006-07 great Alpine fires, and care must be taken when travelling in such areas.

"Safety from hazardous trees is vital for people visiting our forests and parks and for the people who work there, particularly our firefighters undertaking fire suppression or planned burns."

Department of Sustainability and Environment firefighters Steven Kadar and Katie Peters were killed in 2013 when a tree fell on their vehicle in the Buckland Valley.

Coroner John Olle conducted an inquest and recommended the organisation "develop a protocol which best ensures that fire crews are not exposed to fire-affected Alpine ash forests unless absolutely necessary".

"In an ideal world, exposure of fire crews to hazardous trees would be eliminated altogether by finding alternative fire suppression options - in reality however, this is not always possible," he said.

"It is nevertheless critical to appropriately manage the risk posed by hazardous trees in order to minimise the potential for harm to firefighters, specifically through the identification and removal of hazardous trees."

The department agreed to implement all the coroner's findings.

Parks Victoria Kiewa and Murray area chief ranger Dave Jensen said a mechanical falling machine was used to remove hazardous trees.

"The extent of tree removal is dependent upon a number of factors, including the type of trees, the type of road and the side slope," he said.

"The felled timber will remain on the forest floor to provide fauna habitat and nutrients to the soil as the trees decompose."

urn:contentItem:5KSX-7X31-JD34-V4W9-00000-00Research shows burn-offs don't trump mother nature2016-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisResearch shows burn-offs don't trump mother natureJason Walls

New research has called into question the effectiveness of controlled burns in reducing the spread of fires which start during high fire danger periods.

The research paper, co-authored by the University of Melbourne's Kevin Tolhurst AM and the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning's Greg McCarthy AFSM, compared fire severity within a previously burnt area with that of an unburnt area nearby.

It found on severe, extreme or catastrophic (code red) fire danger days "even recent fuel reduction burns may not have much effect on reducing fire severity".

"The most important finding was that the reduction in fire severity and suppression assistance effects of previous fuel-reduction burning started to decline substantially when the [Forest Fire Danger Index] exceeded 50," the paper reads.

"Above FFDI 50, landscapescale fires became 'weather-dominated' and variations in fuel and topography became less important to continued fire spread."

On less severe fire danger days, the researchers found planned burns conducted within the preceding 10 years contributed a "significant proportion of the final fire boundary, confirming the importance of these areas to fire control".

But Associate Professor Tolhurst said even on days when the FFDI exceeded 50, planned burns would still aid firefighters during the cooler periods that followed.

"During the peak of the conditions the fuel reduction will have not much impact, whereas when conditions ease off, later in the evening or subsequent days, it'll make a big difference to the ease of suppressing the fire as well as the extent of the fire," he said.

And even when planned burns did not contribute to a reduction in the overall size of the fire, Associate Professor Tolhurst said they could have important environmental benefits.

"In 1985 at Maryborough, the box ironbark there - which is not dissimilar to the Bendigo forest areas -that had been fuel reduced along some of the major roads," he said.

"It had no impact really on the spread of the fire but it did provide important areas for animals to survive and find food after the fire because they were burnt less severely.

urn:contentItem:5RX8-XYJ1-JD3N-5159-00000-00Hero's mine shafted by bureaucratic backfill2018-03-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Hero's mine shafted by bureaucratic backfillBy PETER HUNT

A BRAVERY medal recipient has been robbed of the mine he dug to escape the memory of seeing his workmate's leg blown off.

Bob Brown had spent two and a half years carving out a small mine at Dunolly in rock-hard ground by hand.

Under his miner's licence, Mr Brown was restricted to using hand tools to sink a 20-foot shaft and 40-foot drive following an alluvial band that occasionally delivered a gram or two of gold to supplement his invalid pension.

But last month, without consultation, Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning staff sent in a dozer to fill the mine, despite Mr Brown surrounding the site with a three-strand wire fence covered in orange bunting.

Mr Brown, who lives 8km from the mine and was off site at the time, arrived the next morning to discover a flattened piece of ground and all his tools buried underground.

"I'm just lucky I wasn't in there at the time," Mr Brown said. "My mine was everything. The solitude took my mind off things." One of those things was the memory of rushing to help his workmate Brian, in a gas explosion in a Queensland gas plant they worked in back in 1999.

Mr Brown was thrown clear in the explosion, but as he got up he heard Brian's screams and went back in to find him.

"When I found him, he was screaming about his legs," Mr Brown said. "When things settled I could see his left leg had gone and was lying eight feet (2.4m) away against a wheelie bin".

Bob received an Australian bravery medal for his actions in September 2000. The Prospectors and Miners Association of Victoria has supported Mr Brown, calling on DELWP to compensate him for the loss of the mine.

Mr Brown said he wanted $7000 to help replace his tools and offset the loss of the mine.

However DELWP Forest Fire Management Victoria Murray Goldfields District manager Paul Bates offered Mr Brown $270 for the loss of his hand tools last Friday, but refused to offer compensation for the mine.

Mr Brown's friend, Andrew Ayres, said DELWP was well aware of the mine, with Mr Bates producing photographs of it, taken 12 months ago.

"It wasn't as though DELWP didn't know about the mine, given Paul Bates had photographs of the mine taken about 12 months ago," Mr Ayres said. "They did more damage to the local bush in 10 minutes than Robert ever did sinking a mine shaft."A DELWP spokesman said the mine shaft was located within a planned burn area scheduled to be carried out this autumn and a decision was made to fill the open shaft for the safety of firefighters and the public. DELWP stated its officers became aware of the mine in 2015 and tried to contact the miner by visiting the site more than a dozen times over the next two years without success.

urn:contentItem:5MNF-XYJ1-JD34-V0NY-00000-00Call to help stop arson2017-01-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Call to help stop arsonEmma D'Agostino

Half of all fires in Victoria are either deliberately lit or the result of reckless conduct.

Country Fire Authority, Forest Fire Management Victoria, Victoria Police, Crime Stoppers and City of Greater Bendigo representatives gathered in Bendigo on Wednesday to appeal for help to reduce that figure.

"People need to be aware of what's happening, especially where they live and travel," CFA community education coordinator Paul Tangey said.

"This year there is a huge risk of grass fire right throughout the stateâ€¦ as well as the bushfires we experience from time to time.

"There is unprecedented growth and we need to be aware of what's happening, we need to keep up with what's going on, and we need to make sure if we see something we say something."

Starting a bushfire because of reckless conduct is mentioned in the same legislation as deliberately starting a fire, Crime Stoppers Victoria community manager Chris Plumridge said.

"Whether it's a campfire on a total fire ban day, or whether you're grinding or welding and there's a spark, reckless bushfire arson can still result in the same tragic consequences as deliberate arson," he said.

Both deliberate and reckless arson are subject to heavy penalties.

Bendigo Detective Acting Inspector Terry Hopley said people could be jailed for up to 15 years for a deliberately lit fire.

The maximum penalty for lighting a fire in an open area during a fire danger period is a $18,500 fine.

Lighting a fire during a Total Fire Ban can result in up to two years of imprisonment or a $37,000 fine.

"We need the community's support in reporting unsafe behaviour so we can stop bushfire arson before it happens," Detective Inspector Hopley said.

"As a community, we owe it to each other to remain vigilant and responsible when out and about this summer."

Mr Plumridge urged people with information to call Crime Stoppers Victoria on 1800 333 000 or to submit a report using the website.

"A report to Crime Stoppers is confidential, so you can report and help keep your community safe without fear of anyone finding out," he said.

In an emergency, people should call 000.

urn:contentItem:5JG2-M2F1-JD67-14BM-00000-00Boost to fire fighting2016-03-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNEWSBoost to fire fighting

Eight new ultra-light fire fighting vehicles with greater water carrying capacity and safety features were delivered to the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning's Daylesford depot this week as part of a statewide upgrade of its fleet.

The ultra-light tankers are among a total of 31 being rolled out across Victoria over the next four weeks, with a further 270 to be delivered over the next four years.

The tankers will be used by Forest Fire Management staff in delivering Victoria's planned burning program and in fire suppression.

DELWP chief fire officer Alan Goodwin said the statewide upgrade was helping to position Victoria as the leader in firefighter vehicle safety.

'These vehicles are modified Mercedes Benz G Wagons and have been specifically fitted out with equipment designed for DELWP's firefighting and planned burning needs,' Mr Goodwin said.

The first group of ultra-light fire tankers was produced for DELWP in 2015, with several additional enhancements added to the latest batch, in an effort to increase crew safety and bushfire response times.

"The upgraded vehicles have a greater water carrying capacity than the older vehicles - 630 litres versus 400 litres - which means firefighters are able to stay longer on the fire ground,' Mr Goodwin said.

"The tankers have a falling object protection structure (FOPS) above the cabin to help protect our crews from falling trees and branches, which is of particular importance because DELWP firefighters work in some of Victoria's toughest and most remote terrain.

'We are the first state in Australia to have implemented this level of falling object protection in our firefighting vehicles.'

The arrival of the ultra-light tankers comes as DELWP starts its autumn planned burning program.

'These tankers are an important investment for the protection of rural and regional communities,' Mr Goodwin said.

'We want to make sure that Victoria is better prepared than ever for bushfires and to carry out bushfire risk reduction work like planned burning.'

urn:contentItem:5TGD-6FP1-JD34-V2RW-00000-00Tower offline at start of fire season2018-10-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Tower offline at start of fire seasonBlake Foden

One of the ACT's fire lookout towers was offline for more than a month at the start of the bushfire season while it was upgraded, following a review conducted after an operator fell through the hatch at another tower in January.

While the Kowen Forest fire tower was offline between August 26 and October 9, encompassing the first five weeks of the bushfire season, Emergency Services Agency commissioner Dominic Lane said the fire danger rating had not reached the point where it needed to be staffed during that period. Mr Lane said bushfire spotters were only required to man the towers when the fire danger rating was "very high" or worse, and community safety was not compromised at any point while the Kowen Forest tower was offline.

The Emergency Services Agency has been upgrading the ACT's four fire towers since the completion of a structural and health and safety review, which followed the January incident at the Mount Coree fire tower.

Mr Lane said a fire tower operator did not close the hatch after entering the tower and fell through the hole, sustaining minor injuries. He was unsure how far the person fell, but they did not fall all the way to the ground and Mr Lane said it "wasn't a great drop".

"There was bruising to the left arm, the left shoulder, the left leg, the right leg and some minor lacerations to the right hand," Mr Lane told the Sunday Canberra Times, adding that the operator made "a rapid recovery".

Mr Lane said the incident prompted the agency to contact WorkSafe and conduct a review of the ACT's fire towers at One Tree Hill in the north, Kowen Forest in the east, Mount Tennent in the south and Mount Coree in the west.

While the review found the January incident was not the result of any structural faults, it uncovered other issues.

Mr Lane said engineers found the platform in the Kowen Forest tower needed to be replaced, while minor upgrades were needed on the tower's access and exit points, meaning it was offline from August 26 until October 9.

"I was very keen to make sure that as we started to get closer to the peak of the fire danger period, that it was done in time," Mr Lane said of the Kowen Forest tower upgrade.

"As it turns out, it was. The tower didn't need to be used between when we said 'don't use it' and when it's come back online the other day."

Mr Lane admitted while the tower was not needed during the time it was offline, it would have been left unmanned even if the fire danger rating required it to be staffed.

"We would never put anyone into a fire tower if it was structurally unsafe," he said.

"I want to make that clear. Fortunately, it didn't matter anyway because we've got it back online before we did need it."

The Mount Coree tower, which the operator fell out of in January, has not been taken offline during upgrades that stemmed from the review. Work on that tower's access and exit points was carried out on September 6 and 7. Additional upgrades will be undertaken on October 15 and 16, but the tower will remain online throughout.

The Mount Tennent tower also stayed online during works between September 19 and 22.

The One Tree Hill tower will be taken offline from October 17 to 19 for upgrades to access and exit points.

Mr Lane said while fire towers were important, they were just one part of the early detection and monitoring of bushfires.

urn:contentItem:5VBY-1281-F0J6-J4VD-00000-00Bushfire warnings 'ignored'2019-02-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Bushfire warnings 'ignored'Liam Mannix, Joshua Whittaker & Katharine Haynes

Australians are still ignoring warnings to leave their homes on catastrophic fire days, 10 years after the Black Saturday bushfires left 173 people dead, new nationwide research finds.

And despite a decade of bushfire fighting reforms, another day like Black Saturday could lead to similar numbers of deaths, a top bushfire expert warns.

This comes as the Country Fire Authority's top officer warns Victorians: "We won't compromise the safety of our crew when you made a decision to stay there after we'd advised you to leave."

Black Saturday's fires flared up in the worst conditions in Australia's records. On Febuary 7, 2009, a new record maximum temperature of 46.4C was set in Melbourne, and the forest fire danger index reached 170; far higher than 1983's Ash Wednesday or 1939's Black Friday.

If we got a repeat those conditions, we could expect the same number of fatalities, says Professor Ross Bradstock, one of Australia's leading bushfire experts.

"If you were to replay the scenario, the weather, the ignition points and timing, I would say you'd get roughly the same result. All bets are off under those conditions. The sort of weather we saw, it was probably the worst fire weather in the world. It's a turbocharged furnace."

He did not suggest we had learnt nothing from the disaster.

"We can tinker with our systems, our evacuations, our warnings. But it's so far off the scale, you have to question whether any of the things we do can make a difference."

The bushfire royal commission led to several key changes in the way we warn communities - warnings are sent via SMS and apps almost as soon as fires break out. The biggest change has been the shift in messaging, away from a choice of 'stay or go', toward urging people to leave early.

On Black Saturday, even the most-prepared residents found property defence challenging, and many were overwhelmed by fire.

Now, official advice on extreme fire danger days is that even the best-prepared homes will not be safe, and that leaving the night before or early in the day is the safest option.

But research undertaken through the Bushfire & Natural Hazards CRC suggests while the message may have changed since Black Saturday, people are choosing to stay even when advised to leave.

A significant number of people tell researchers they simply won't leave until a bushfire breaks out nearby.

Many won't even leave if a bushfire does break out - waiting for it to directly threaten them, which can lead to dangerous late evacuations, or being trapped at an unprepared property.

Some people remain unaware of bushfire risk and many do not, or can not, adequately plan and prepare for a bushfire.

The CFA wants to make it very clear: people who do not get out of harm's way cannot expect to be saved.

When a fire threatened houses in Hepburn Springs on Saturday, police door-knocked 70 houses by 3am, urging people to leave.

"Even at that point, people chose to stay," says Steve Warrington, the CFA's chief officer. "We made it really clear - we won't be sending a fire truck up your street. We won't compromise the safety of our crew when you made a decision to stay there after we'd advised you to leave."

Mr Warrington says there's only so much his firefighters can do.

"The big gap is the community not recognising what they have to do. Communities still think they are going to get a fire truck."

If Black Saturday were to happen again, "I suspect we will lose houses. But if people aren't there, we won't lose life," Mr Warrington said.

"I'd be devastated if people in Marysville and Kinglake were still in their houses on a Code Red day."

Dr Josh Whittaker is a bushfire researcher at the University of Wollongong and Dr Katharine Haynes is a human geographer at Macquarie University. Liam Mannix is The Age's science reporter.

urn:contentItem:5XVP-KJN1-F0J6-J165-00000-00Bushfire Emergency warning for Wingan River, Mallacoota2019-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisBushfire Emergency warning for Wingan River, MallacootaBen Smyth

Sunday, 8.45pm:

An out of control bushfire at Wingan River has increased rapidly in size and has already burnt approximately 1200ha

The fire is approximately 20km east of Cann River.

The bushfire is travelling in a southerly direction towards the coast.

The Princes Highway has been re-opened. However, all roads into the fire area are closed including the West Wingan Road. Avoid the area if you can to allow free access to all emergency vehicles.

Campers have been evacuated from Wingan Inlet camp ground and other camp grounds within Croajingolong National Park.

Hikers are being evacuated from the Croajingolong National Park Wilderness Coast Walk.

Leaving now is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous

Scroll down for additional safety advice and contacts UPDATE, Sunday 5.10pm: The Princes Hwy is closed between Monaro Hwy and Mallacoota-Genoa Rd due to bushfire. Avoid the area.

EARLIER: The outbreak of a bushfire at Wingan River has resulted in an Emergency warning being issued for that community Sunday afternoon.

The same fire is on Watch and Act for Genoa, Gipsy Point, Karbethong, Mallacoota, Maramingo Creek, and Wangarabell.

The out of control bushfire is at Wingan River in East Gippsland just south of the Princes Hwy, approximately 28km east of Cann River.

The bushfire is travelling in a north-westerly direction towards the Princes Highway.

Firefighters and aircraft are responding to the fire.

Leaving now is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous.

Emergency Services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.

However, if you are in Mallacoota, stay there. Official advice from Forest Fire Management Victoria is it is too late to leave. Staying in Mallacoota is your safest option.

There is also a separate Watch and Act alert for East Gippsland communities including Bonang and Goongerah further west, with residents right across the north-east Victorian shire told to leave now if they can. Visitors are being urged to leave the area before Monday's expected challenging weather.

READ ALSO: Bonang, Goongerah fire at Watch and Act, residents told to evacuate now

What you should do:

You should leave using West Wingan Road and head towards Cann River.

The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area.

When you leave remember to take your pets, mobile phone and medications.

In the car:

If you are travelling, do not enter the area. U-turn to safety.

Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.

If you are unable to leave you should shelter indoors:

Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.

You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you.

Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.

If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt.

If you cannot get indoors, other last resort options include:

Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.

Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.

Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.

If you are caught in fire in your car:

Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.

Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.

Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.

Close all windows.

Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.

Turn your car engine off.

Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.

Impacts in your area:

Embers are being carried by the wind large distances ahead of the main fire and starting spot fires.

Bushfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the fire reaches you.

Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

Health information:

If you need medical advice for burns or exposure to smoke, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

Anyone experiencing wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call Triple Zero (000).

If you can see or smell smoke, please note:

Smoke can affect people's health.

People with pre-existing health problems, heart or lung conditions (including asthma), children, pregnant women and older people are more sensitive to the effects of breathing in smoke.

People with existing heart or lung conditions (including asthma) should follow the treatment plan advised by the doctor.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

www.emergency.vic.gov.au

VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.

VicEmergency app.

Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).

Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:

The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.

To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.

If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

urn:contentItem:5RRY-X4W1-JD34-V19X-00000-00Two out-of-control grassfires burn near Western Freeway2018-02-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisTwo out-of-control grassfires burn near Western FreewaySiobhan Calafiore and Patrick Nolan

UPDATE, 5pm:

Country Fire Authority District 15 duty officer Kade Dowie has praised efforts of crews as a spate of fires broke out across Ballarat on Sunday afternoon.

He said the fire on the Western Freeway had now been contained, but crews would remain on the scene later this evening and overnight to patrol and mop up the flanks of the fire.

The fire had been headed in a northerly direction due to the strong winds and was contained before reaching Olliers Road in Mount Rowan.

The cause of the fire is under investigation with CFA and Victoria Police following standard policy.

Duty Officer Dowie said there had been 20 CFA appliances on scene attending to the fire, as well as a fire bombing helicopter and an observation air craft.

He said Forest Fire Management Victoria is also on scene to help clean up trees in the area, but the early indication is there has been no structural damage and no injuries, however there is the potential for fences to have been damaged.

He could not clarify whether the fires on either side of Creswick Road on the Western Freeway were part of the same fire or separate, and determining this would be part of the investigation.

Meanwhile, another grass fire in Napoleons started between 2.30pm and 2.45pm on Sunday.

Duty Officer Dowie said this fire had been contained "really quickly" by the 12 crews on scene.

The fire was about five hectares in size and there had been no damage or injuries.

The cause of this fire is also under investigation.

UPDATE, 4.15pm: The fire near Napoleons has now been declared under control.

However, fire crews are expected to remain on scene for some time and smoke may still be visible in the area.

It is not known how it started.

As for the fire near the Western Freeway, it is now listed as being contained.

UPDATE, 3.55pm: One of the fires is now under control and firefighters are focusing their efforts on the fire closer to Invermay.

There are currently 21 units battling that particular blaze.

However, another fire has broken out in Napoleons, to the south of Ballarat.

Sixteen units are currently fighting that fire, which is burning in the bush near Natrass Road.

Winds are still hovering around 50km/h, although there have been 63km/h gusts recorded from the south-east.

2.30pm: Two out-of-control grassfires have started near the Western Freeway to Ballarat's north.

One fire is burning near the Creswick Road/Midland Highway overpass, while another is burning further along the highway towards Invermay.

The fires are being fuelled by winds up to 50km/h.

There are at least six CFA units on scene at the Creswick Road fire, while there are 13 at the Invermay blaze.

Air support has also been requested.

The fires started just after 2pm and are about two kilometres apart.

It is not yet know how they started, although police are investigating.

People are advised to avoid the area.

More to come.

urn:contentItem:5RRY-STR1-JD34-V1H0-00000-00Wedge-tailed eagle sparks fire on Panmure dairy farm2018-02-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisWedge-tailed eagle sparks fire on Panmure dairy farmKatrina Lovell

A wedge-tailed eagle sitting on a powerline sparked a paddock fire on a Panmure dairy farm on Monday.

Farmer Peter Moir had almost finished milking his cows about 5.45pm when he heard the wind change and popped his head outside the dairy to check it out and noticed a puff of white smoke.

With winds gusting at up to 50 km/h, he immediately called 000, cleared the cows out of the way and by then Panmure fire brigade had arrived.

By the time they'd reached the fire, which was about 800 metres from the dairy and his house, the fire had already burnt across the paddock to the dirt track.

And while the willow trees on the other side of the track were scorched by the heat, firefighters were able to stop the blaze from spreading to the next paddock or the Framlingham Forest which was about 1km away.

"It was just lucky the track had pulled it up and the Panmure tanker stopped it there."

Another six or eight tankers and bomber planes from Hamilton helped bring it under control within 45 minutes.

"It was just unusual the way it burnt because it was an easterly wind. If it had been a northerly wind it would have blown to the houses or dairy," Mr Moir said.

"It just shows how easily it can happen on a day you wouldn't expect.

"If it had been 32 degrees instead of 22 degrees they would have been at the neighbour's place to stop it before it reached the bush."

The fire brought back memories of the January 10 Framlingham Forest fire that burnt the western boundary of his property 11 years ago.

The eagle, which was found dead in the paddock, was believed to have hit the powerline and sparked the blaze.

Mr Moir said that there had been a breeding pair of wedge-tailed eagles that had lived in a big gum tree on the edge of the Framlingham Forest for more than 20 years.

And even though that tree was burnt in the fire a decade ago, the eagles could be seen every two years flying around the area with their young. "We're just hoping it's not one of the breeding pair," Mr Moir said.

Mr Moir said he was impressed with how well organised the CFA was and how quickly they contained the blaze.

Crews spent two hours mopping up after the blaze and Mr Moir spent the night regularly checking on it, including getting up at 4am.

"All farmers do, you feel a responsibility even though there's no fault or blame anywhere. Then you think sure I could have rolled over and slept til 6.30am and then got up. If I hadn't got up two hours before and it had flared up and all of a sudden my neighbour's place is on fire because I didn't check it....that's what you do."

Region 5 operations operations manager Richard Bourke said the rapid response from the brigades and planes helped contain the blaze to under five hectares.

urn:contentItem:5MFX-P841-JD34-V4BB-00000-00LIVING near public land where,...2016-12-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 2LIVING near public land where,...

LIVING near public land where, in 2009, the Black Saturday bushfire decimated homes and communities, the residents of Sparrowhawk and Empire roads know all too well the importance of fire safety.

So there was an air of disbelief as about 15 residents were forced to stand and watch while firefighters fought a blaze late Thursday night, where a fireworks canister was later found.

The Price household was settled in for the evening at their Lancashire Street home - between Sparrowhawk and Empire roads - when sounds similar to gun shots rung out just before 11pm.

"My son first heard it and we had no idea what it was," Lynton Price said.

They headed outside and spotted a group of young people fleeing south from Empire Road into nearby bushland as fire took hold.

"They seemed to be hanging around a little while to see what happened next, then they were gone," Mr Price said.

"The fire really got going among the trees, some of the trees exploded."

Fire quickly took hold in public land alongside their neighbour's house, running up trees and threatening one home.

It failed to breach a side fence and was contained in the parcel of public land.

As six CFA units fought the fire, his neighbour spotted a fireworks canister on the side of the road.

They handed it over to police investigators who were treating the fire as suspicious.

"Once we saw the canister, we knew they'd been letting off fireworks," Mr Price said.

The fire burnt over half a hectare.

Forest fire management Victoria district duty officer Jeff Wilkie said crews had the blaze under control at 3.30am.

"Fire crews will be patrolling and blacking out the area over the next few days," he said.

The fire is being treated as suspicious and police are investigating. Anyone with information is encouraged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

Firefighters were also called to a small blaze near the old Eaglehawk Golf Club on Friday morning.

Five CFA trucks attended the scene on Golf Links Road in Maiden Gully just after 7am and had the fire under control in 15 minutes. It burnt about one acre.

Visit www.bendigoadvertiser.com.au to watch firefighters battle the blaze on Empire Road.
