urn:contentItem:544B-SGN1-F0N8-R15V-00000-00After the floods, grassy plains fuel fears2011-10-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNEWS REVIEWPg. 13After the floods, grassy plains fuel fearsNicky Phillips

A thick blanket of dry vegetation is becoming a growing danger, writes Nicky Phillips. It's said that bad luck comes in threes. After a drought that lasted a decade and crippled much of the state, the rains came, flooding vast expanses of eastern Australia. And while the record rainfall this year brought many regions back to life it has also encouraged a blanket of grass to advance across the state, transforming large parts of NSW, and Australia, into a significant fuel source for bushfires.

Forest fires in Katoomba this week signalled the bushfire season is upon us. Yet it is the tall, thick band of fine fuel which extends from Queensland to Victoria; and west of the Great Dividing Range to South Australia that poses the real danger. Despite the Bureau of Meteorology's forecast for above average rainfall through spring and summer, fire experts say it takes only a week of hot, rain-free weather for grass to "cure" or dry out, turning much of the state into a fire hazard. The bureau predicts above average summer temperatures for southern parts of the state, while northern regions should experience temperatures slightly below average. The Commissioner of the NSW Rural Fire Service, Shane Fitzsimmons, says more than 2000 grass fires have ignited since July. Despite the forecast of a weaker La Nina this year, parts of the state are unlikely to get away unscathed. "Across NSW we've got grassland fuel loads the likes of which we have not seen for 30 or 40 years," he says. The last time the state had similar levels of grass growth was in the summer of 1984-85, when six people died and 40,000 head of stock were destroyed by fires that raged across more than 4.5 million hectares, he says. Any rain over spring and summer would have no effect on the grass that has already grown and cured over the past 18 months, Fitzsimmons says. "It's all dry, it's all dead," he says. Rain that fell on partially cured grass would extend the drying process. "We're happy to see the La Nina outlook, but we need to make sure that doesn't put into place a false sense of security, complacency or apathy," Fitzsimmons says. Melbourne University fire ecologist Dr Kevin Tolhurst says the fine fuel nature of grass made it easy to ignite, often by lightning strikes. But the main danger of grass fires is their speed, he says. "Typically a grass fire over an hour will average about 20 to 22 kilometres, where as a forest fire going between two and five kilometres an hour is [considered] a pretty fast forest fire," Tolhurst says. Though he adds that grass fires are usually not as intense. "The heat output is much less and the time taken for a fire to burn out is much quicker," Tolhurst says. The behaviour of a grass fire will depend on whether there are trees in the landscape. "If trees are present, then spotting, the process of numerous new fires starting ahead of the main fire front, is much more likely." In pure grassland fires, spotting is limited which makes them more controllable and easier to predict, he says. While their speed can catch people unawares, historically forest fires cause the most damage to houses and properties. "In a forest fire you might be burning something between 10 and 50 tonne of fuel per hectare. In a grassland area you are probably burning between two and six tonnes per hectare," Tolhurst says. It is easier for people or their property to become trapped in a forest fire rather than be overrun by it, he says. To predict grassland fire danger, the NSW Rural Fire Service combines weather data from the Bureau of Meteorology with satellite data and field reports on the amount of grass, measured in tonnes per hectare, and the degree it is cured or dried. The manager of community planning at the service, Dr Simon Heemstra, says satellite images provided by the bureau, capture the colour or "greenness" of the vegetation, which can be used to estimate the amount of moisture in the fuel. "The colour from green to straw to light brown gives us an estimate of the percentage cured," Heemstra says. But the images can give false low readings if there is too much green tree canopy. "Once we get over 70 per cent cured, we are starting to get into a situation where you could have bad fires," he says. The amount of fuel per hectare is measured by field reports. "At the moment it is continuous across most of NSW," he says . "In some cases we are getting it up to people's armpits." Once fuel conditions have been calculated they are combined with the daily temperature, relative humidity and wind speed to give what is called a Grassland Fire Danger Index. This index gives a scale of how difficult a fire under those specific conditions will be to control. Dr Andrew Sullivan, a senior research scientist at CSIRO, says historically the index was a ranking between 0 and 100. However advances in weather and fuel data means that the scale is now open-ended. "Once you get an FDI above 50, it is very difficult to do anything about it," Sullivan says. "You are now into the realm of we'll do the best we can, but the conditions are pretty bad." Once a grass land fire has ignited, fire managers use a model developed by CSIRO to predict the rate of spread and intensity of the fire. Sullivan, who helped develop the model, says it takes into account the weather as well as the type of pasture such as natural ungrazed grass land, mown fields or paddocks eaten out by stock. "If you know where a fire started you can use the model to determine what its average speed will be, and then for a given length of time how far it will travel," Sullivan says. It can also predict the fire's shape and the height of the flames, although its overall accuracy depends on the reliability of the input values such as weather data and fuel conditions, he says. After a busy start to the bushfire season, Fitzsimmons says landowners need to prepare their properties for bushfire season, with appropriate firebreaks in grassy regions. "The real key is everyone should have a bushfire survival plan."

urn:contentItem:5NBS-K6K1-DY19-C3D2-00000-00Smoke haze and fog blankets city2017-04-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisSmoke haze and fog blankets cityEbony Bowden

Melbourne is blanketed in a veil of smoke haze and fog as dozens of planned burns smoulder around the state.

Melbourne is blanketed in a veil of smoke haze and fog as dozens of planned burns smoulder around the state.

Commuters this morning may smell smoke in the air as fire management authorities make the most of ideal conditions for the burns.

Melbourne's skyline is also obscured by fog expected to last throughout the morning until an unseasonable high of 26 degrees this afternoon.

A handful of flights at Melbourne Airport were cancelled this morning due to the foggy conditions, while motorists are being urged to take extra care on the roads.

The fog was so thick the city skyline was not visible from North Melbourne.

Large fires of up to 2000 hectares are being patrolled by Forest Fire Management Victoria in locations such as Myrtleford, Bright, Marysville, Lakes Entrance and Bendigo.

Bureau of Meteorology forecaster Keris Arndt said this morning's fog was slowly lifting and clear by around 10am as the mercury rises.

Fog hides the Melbourne CBD from North Melbourne this morning. Photo: Supplied

"We get these kinds of fogs this time of year. There's plenty of moisture around and the nights are getting longer. There's also little to no wind around at the moment so perfect ingredients for fog."

"We're seeing pretty widespread fog over southern Victoria at the moment including Melbourne, but as we speak it's clearing at the airport and lifting in the city.

"It's almost more a blanket of very low cloud at the moment. We will continue to see conditions improve and it should be pretty clear by 9 to 10 am."

The sun tries to barge through fog over the Queen Victoria Market on Wednesday. Photo: Supplied

Mr Arndt said smoke haze would linger throughout Wednesday after a nocturnal inversion overnight which creates a layer of warm air, trapping smoke and fog.

"That's when we get those really hazy, polluted-looking mornings," he said.

"As we warm up it should clear up so throughout the morning but there will still be some smoke around."

Air quality in Melbourne will be fair on Wednesday, but areas including Macleod, Point Cook, Altona have been downgraded to poor.

Geelong air quality is also reading as very poor, according to Environmental Protection Authority Victoria.

Melbourne's temperature is expected to peak at 26 degrees at about 2pm, an unseasonably warm day for April.

The average peak temperature for April is 20.3 degrees.

urn:contentItem:5MD7-5921-JD3N-52S5-00000-00Joining the fight on bushfire prevention2016-12-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Joining the fight on bushfire preventionBRUCE MOUNSTER

THE state's $28.5 million, four-year fuel reduction burning program has reached the halfway mark and Tasmanians are paying a lot more attention to associated fire safety measures, says the program's chief promoter.

State Fire Management Council (SFMC) chairman Ian Sauer said councils and landowners were embracing bushfire mitigation and had begun co-operating with each other and the state's fire fighting agencies in ways not seen elsewhere in Australia.

Mr Sauer said a fuel reduction burn started yesterday near Legana was an example of co-operation involving Grindelwald owner Tamar Valley Resort, forestry company Forico, the Parks and Wildlife Service, ForestryTasmania and the Tasmania Fire Service.

He said 30 burns had already been completed in Tasmania this year and another 75 were ready as soon as climatic conditions allowed.

University of Tasmania bushfire ecologist David Bowman said such interest in fuel reduction, to make wildfires burning near populated areas more manageable, could not come a moment too soon.

He said last year's dry had set the state up for a horror forest fire season, particularly in remote areas, while this year's hazard appeared to be enormous amounts of grass growing near populated areas, and rapidly drying out thanks to this month's strong winds.

"This is a mirror image to last summer, with all this rain," Prof Bowman said. He said time was running out for the removal of grass, which could have the same effect as a "moat filled with petrol" if allowed to dry near homes and public areas.

Mr Sauer said Hobart City Council, with its well established fire management protocols, had been a "leading light, and other Tasmanian councils were grasping the nettle".

Glenorchy City Council this week announced an upgrade of its bushfire mitigation program, including the creation of a new bushfire management co-ordinator position.

Mayor Kristie Johnston said the council was developing plans to mitigate bushfire impacts including fuel reduction burns, vegetation slashing, fire trail maintenance and land holder communication.

Clarence City Council's bushfire management strategy has been in place since 2011.TFS's bushfire-ready neighbourhoods program, an SFMC initiative which includes landowner discussions, has won a best practice in behavioural change award from the Institute of Public Administration.

urn:contentItem:5S7W-SRF1-JD3N-5015-00000-00You can't be serious?2018-05-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 57You can't be serious?

TIM Pallas' extraordinary claims that he defends and would have gladly joined the red shirts campaign rort only leads to the most basic question of why the money has been repaid, if his view is the ALP has done no wrong?

And why compound the fiasco with endless legal costs to block the Ombudsman? Mal Alexander, Vermont

Get your hand out I OBJECT to how gleefully politicians spend billions of our dollars. The bigger the amount of B spent, the better. They think somehow the B word impresses us. It is just a reminder that spending and blatant vote buying is out of control.

They should be trying to get out of our collective pockets, not pushing their hand in deeper and then crowing about it.

Justin Robertson, Carnegie

Sign of the times THERE is nothing wrong with the state of our country roads. The asphalt that connects the potholes is usually in reasonable shape.

On the Kyneton to Redesdale road, there is a sign that states: "We will be fixing this road soon." I don't know how long the sign has been there but it looks like it needs to be renewed, too.

Phil Browne, Woodend

See through the smoke DARYL Young (Text Talk, May 2) blames the CFA for ruining his autumn day with smoke.

His local CFA volunteers can explain how they are not lighting the burns (it's Forest Fire Management) and how a burn in the right place can help them to protect a suburb like Doreen, which is surrounded on three sides by bush and rural countryside.

P.J. Bear, Mitcham

Dividends not endless MEL (Hot Topic, May 3), in order to make a profit of $640,000 in three years from shares (and presumably not from an overly large outlay, since you couldn't afford enough of a deposit to buy a house), you must have been either an extremely lucky or an extremely savvy investor.

Not a recommended strategy for the average Joe Blow.

John Howes, Rowville

Blues let us down HERE are some questions being asked by lifelong Carlton supporters. Why have we given away so many great players now starring for other clubs? Where are our top-class key position players, ie full-forward, full-back? When are we going to address skill errors including missing easy goals, dropping easy marks, too much ineffective handball, fumbling and how about a little more "man-up" instead of allowing opponents to run free?

When are we going to play four quarters instead of one or two and going to sleep for the rest?

How are we going to hold on to promising young players who will be offered more money from clubs with greater potential for success?

Over to you, Blues.

G. Green, Albury, NSW

Lift your game, Joe DAVID Zaharakis claims that Joe Daniher's role as a forward is about more than kicking goals.

I disagree. A forward must kick goals for his team to win. Kicking seven goals from six games won't cut it in today's game.

This year, Joe has failed to kick goals or assist teammates, and repeatedly turned the ball over to opponents. Let's hope his 100th game is more memorable than his last six.David Clifton, Blackburn

urn:contentItem:5V6X-P3V1-JD34-V234-00000-00Fire leaves long road to healing2019-01-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisWRAPPg. 4Fire leaves long road to healingCarly Werner

CONTAINING the Northern Grampians Complex fire was just the first step towards recovery.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said the months after the fire involved rehabilitation and recovery work across both public land and private property.

"Hundreds of kilometers of burnt fences had to be cleared and rebuilt, water used in the firefight had to be replaced, public roads had to be assessed for dangerous trees and treated before reopening for public access, and much livestock was burnt that had to be assessed and dealt with," he said.

"A significant number of buildings and dwellings had been burnt, requiring follow-up with insurance companies, and the challenges of rebuilding or moving.

"The mental impacts of events like these are long-term and no doubt still being felt today."

Mr Rudolph said the fire's impact on the environment was difficult to measure.

"We know the Australian bush, particularly in this part of the world, is quite well adapted to fire," he said.

"Fire is a natural part of the landscape, and humans have been propagating fires for many reasons for thousands of years.

"It's a complex situation.

"Seasonal rainfall also has a major impact on how the bush recovers. In continual drought conditions species recover slower and are probably more vulnerable to repeated fire events or other threats such as predation by foxes, or disease."

Mr Rudolph said there had been a lot of work done since 2006 to determine how certain species responded to fire in the Grampians.

"For example a long-term mammal monitoring program was set up by Parks Victoria, which has shown some interesting trends including the importance of seasonal rainfall, but also the value of protecting certain areas from fire such as damp gullies that some species use as refuge in drought years," he said.

"After the Mt Lubra fire some very rare plant species were found to regenerate in large numbers, suggesting that those species do require fire at some interval in their life cycle.

"Very simply though there's a strong consensus that large intense bushfires are not beneficial and not the type of fire that the landscape requires, especially in such short time frames."

Mr Rudolph said the Northern Grampians Complex fire was the third large landscape-scale fire the Grampians had experienced in eight years.

It followed the Mt Lubra fire in 2006, the largest fire on record in the Grampians, which burnt more than 120,000 hectares. The Victoria Valley fire in 2013 burnt 35,000 hectares.

"Nearly 87 per cent of the park had been burnt in less than 10 years, often in extremely intense fires," Mr Rudolph said.

"About 10,000 hectares of the Northern Grampians Complex fire area had been burnt in the 2006 Mt Lubra fire, a stark reminder of how quickly the Australian bush can carry fire again after even intense bushfires.

"These are unprecedented fires since European history began, in terms of their scale and time scale between.

"Prior to the last decade, on average the Grampians experienced a large fire in the order of 10 to 20,000 hectares once every 30 or so years.

"To have three in such short succession is telling us something about the state of the environment. The millennium drought was a significant event that affected the whole landscape including agriculture, water storages and bushfire impacts.

"These events are predicted to happen more often and we need to be prepared for them."

Mr Rudolph said the Wimmera had experienced several other large fires on both public land and private property since the mid 2000s.

He said the implications of this for bushfire management extended to planned burning; consideration for how and where houses were built; landowner preparedness for fires; and partnerships between private land owners and public land authorities to reduce fuels around towns and communities.

"No one organisation or person owns all the risk - working together is a key solution to this," he said.

urn:contentItem:5K5W-X421-JD67-101J-00000-00A collaborative approach2016-07-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisNEWSA collaborative approachNatalie Croxon

THE traditional owners of the land are becoming increasingly involved in its management, to the benefit of both the Aboriginal community and the government.

In 2013 the corporation and the state government entered into a recognition and settlement agreement, formally recognising the Dja Dja Wurrung people as the traditional owners of more than 266,500 hectares of public land in central Victoria.

Since then, Dja Dja Wurrung people have become increasingly engaged in fuel reduction and forestry thinning activities carried out by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning.

'We've built a very strong relationship in a short time,' DELWP forest fire management regional manager Scott Falconer said.

A team of employees from the Dja Dja Wurrung Corporation have been working with the DELWP to undertake forestry thinning and supply firewood to the community.

Mr Falconer said Dja Dja Wurrung people had also been brought on board with fuel reduction implementation and planning, so they could both give their input and better understand the process.

The partnership between the department and the Dja Dja Wurrung people had numerous benefits, he said.

Mr Falconer said it presented the opportunity to combine contemporary knowledge and science with tens of thousands of years of stewardship experience and traditional knowledge.

'I'm genuinely excited to have the marrying of these two knowledge sets,' he said.

The department was also able to tap into a knowledge set it did not have previously, he said, which had led to fresh ideas.

Mr Falconer said one example was the suggestion from Aboriginal workers that burns be carried out not only for fuel reduction, but also to allow for the growing of yams.

Aboriginal employees can also provide an insight into their community's burning priorities.

Dja Dja Wurrung Clans Aboriginal Corporation chief executive officer Rodney Carter said working with the DELWP was bringing real meaning to the recognition and settlement agreement for Aboriginal people.

The partnership has also provided training and accreditation opportunities.

Mr Falconer said he hoped the collaboration between the department and the Dja Dja Wurrung people would continue to grow into the future.

urn:contentItem:5N86-V7M1-F031-X31J-00000-00Smoky Melbourne: Haze hangs over city as planned burns continue across Victoria2017-04-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexisSmoky Melbourne: Haze hangs over city as planned burns continue across Victoria

Melbourne's week of hazy mornings has continued today, as fire authorities make up for lost time igniting more than 100 controlled burns across Victoria.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief fire officer Stephanie Rotarangi said Victorians could expect a reprieve from the smoky conditions over the weekend, before burning recommenced next week.

"We're still behind schedule on the number of planned burns that we would have hoped to have achieved at this time, but the season has been quite late - March was a bit variable - so this is the first settled period that we've had," she said.

"We'll continue to make the most of every opportunity, while attempting to minimise the impact of smoke.

"Next week is also looking pretty settled for planned burning, so we will make use of the opportunities across the state to reduce that fuel."

Most of the burns have been in Gippsland, the Hume region, the Yarra Valley and around Lorne on the south coast.

There are more than 20 burns still in progress.

Air quality warnings issued

An emergency alert issued on Thursday for poor air quality in Mooroolbark because of smoke from several planned burns remains in place.

Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) executive director Tim Eaton said people aged over 65, young children, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions were most at risk of health issues from the smoke.

"In those sensitive groups people normally have for example asthma management plans or plans from their doctor if they've got a lung condition or that sort of thing," he said.

"We simply ask that they follow those plans."

Ms Rotarangi said fire management consulted with the EPA and the Bureau of Meteorology before commencing planned burns.

"There was a little bit of extra smoke in the city yesterday, but that's just bearing in mind that we're not the only ones making use of these conditions, there has been a number of private burns as well as our burns," she said.

She said while the haze had made for some "pretty" sunrises this week, fire authorities would continue to try to minimise smoke from the burns.

"We're also really conscious that planned burning does affect people, particularly their ability to enjoy the conditions outside and we're just really thanking Victorians for their patience, it's an important program and the whole point of it is to stop bushfires."

urn:contentItem:5T8T-VVN1-JBJ7-N18S-00000-00'Not the details requested': EPA, RFS, others rebuke Santos over CSG2018-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:39:34ZLexisNexis'Not the details requested': EPA, RFS, others rebuke Santos over CSGPeter Hannam

Government agencies have reiterated demands for more information from Santos about its plan to develop a $3 billion coal seam gas project in northern NSW, saying the company had failed to respond to their concerns.

NSW government agencies have reiterated demands for more information from Santos about its plan to develop a $3 billion coal seam gas project in northern NSW, saying the company had failed to respond to their concerns.

A dozen agencies, including the Environment Protection Authority and the Rural Fire Service, have released their responses to Santos' answers to 23,000 submissions to its Narrabri environmental impact statement.

Unresolved issues include how Santos will dispose of salt generated from the 850 planned wells. Over 25 years, the gasfield is expect to produce more than 430,000 tonnes of the material.

The EPA had demanded Santos state where the waste would go, noting it had "the potential to create a large point of source of salt in the environment if not disposed of appropriately", and that the company's response "did not provide the details requested".

"The EPA expects that many, if not all, landfill facilities in the local government area will not have the capacity to receive the quantity of salt (and other waste) generated by the project," the agency said.

The watchdog's other concerns include whether the proposed water monitoring capacity was sufficient to detect changes in water quality, and inadequate assessment of fugitive emissions of the potent greenhouse gas methane.

The use of just four months' of ambient air monitoring for nitrogen dioxide and ozone was also "not general practice in NSW", the EPA said.

Santos responds

A Santos spokeswoman said the company would only take the salt "to a facility licensed for this purpose". The project would also produce 48 tonnes per day, less than half the salt now being produced by AGL's Liddell and Bayswater power stations.

"Santos has already advised the EPA that it will do further work on its Water Monitoring Plan prior to project determination," she said, noting it was also working with the EPA to address fugitive emissions worries.

The drawn-out approval process has prompted some analysts to doubt the project will ever win approval, not least because of the prospect that proposed gas import terminals will undermine its economic viability.

The RFS' concerns include the possibility that CSG could provide "a pathway for fire to the underground coal seam", and a demand that "no gas flaring shall be undertaken on extreme and/or catastrophic fire weather days".

Santos had also failed to address "the risk to firefighters, with respect to managing and extinguishing a forest fire in the state forests", the RFS said. Much of the proposed gasfield sits within the Pilliga State Forest.

The Santos spokeswoman said it was "simply not possible for underground coal ignition to occur as a result of CSG development".

"It is untrue that there is any increased risk of fire spreading or increased danger to firefighters arising from the presence of [CSG] infrastructure," she said, adding the company already had a bushfire management plan developed in consultation with the RFS.

Georgina Woods, a coordinator with the Lock the Gate alliance, said it was "shocking for Santos to dismiss RFS' concerns".

"There's no requirement for them to stop flaring on high fire danger days," she said.

She noted the Department of Planning and the Environment (DPE) had sought a meeting with Santos to discuss agency concerns "in more detail", but it was unclear what the results were.

"We are dependent on the DPE to hold the line on the adequacy and the rigour of the assessment" of the project before it goes to the Independent Planning Commission for a determination, Ms Woods said.

NSW government agencies have reiterated demands for more information from Santos about its plan to develop a $3 billion coal seam gas project in northern NSW, saying the company had failed to respond to their concerns.

A dozen agencies, including the Environment Protection Authority and the Rural Fire Service, have released their responses to Santos' answers to 23,000 submissions to its Narrabri environmental impact statement.

Unresolved issues include how Santos will dispose of salt generated from the 850 planned wells. Over 25 years, the gasfield is expect to produce more than 430,000 tonnes of the material.

The EPA had demanded Santos state where the waste would go, noting it had "the potential to create a large point of source of salt in the environment if not disposed of appropriately", and that the company's response "did not provide the details requested".

"The EPA expects that many, if not all, landfill facilities in the local government area will not have the capacity to receive the quantity of salt (and other waste) generated by the project," the agency said.

The watchdog's other concerns include whether the proposed water monitoring capacity was sufficient to detect changes in water quality, and inadequate assessment of fugitive emissions of the potent greenhouse gas methane.

The use of just four months' of ambient air monitoring for nitrogen dioxide and ozone was also "not general practice in NSW", the EPA said.

Santos responds

A Santos spokeswoman said the company would only take the salt "to a facility licensed for this purpose". The project would also produce 48 tonnes per day, less than half the salt now being produced by AGL's Liddell and Bayswater power stations.

"Santos has already advised the EPA that it will do further work on its Water Monitoring Plan prior to project determination," she said, noting it was also working with the EPA to address fugitive emissions worries.

The drawn-out approval process has prompted some analysts to doubt the project will ever win approval, not least because of the prospect that proposed gas import terminals will undermine its economic viability.

The RFS' concerns include the possibility that CSG could provide "a pathway for fire to the underground coal seam", and a demand that "no gas flaring shall be undertaken on extreme and/or catastrophic fire weather days".

Santos had also failed to address "the risk to firefighters, with respect to managing and extinguishing a forest fire in the state forests", the RFS said. Much of the proposed gasfield sits within the Pilliga State Forest.

The Santos spokeswoman said it was "simply not possible for underground coal ignition to occur as a result of CSG development".

"It is untrue that there is any increased risk of fire spreading or increased danger to firefighters arising from the presence of [CSG] infrastructure," she said, adding the company already had a bushfire management plan developed in consultation with the RFS.

Georgina Woods, a coordinator with the Lock the Gate alliance, said it was "shocking for Santos to dismiss RFS' concerns".

"There's no requirement for them to stop flaring on high fire danger days," she said.

She noted the Department of Planning and the Environment (DPE) had sought a meeting with Santos to discuss agency concerns "in more detail", but it was unclear what the results were.

"We are dependent on the DPE to hold the line on the adequacy and the rigour of the assessment" of the project before it goes to the Independent Planning Commission for a determination, Ms Woods said.
